docs.snippet: LEAD: Washington, full of sanctimony, is about to blow its annual trade whistle again. It's time for the self-appointed cop to back off.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Washington, full of sanctimony, is about to blow its annual trade whistle again. It's time for the self-appointed cop to back off.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that based on a review of bank records seized in Panama after the American invasion, as well as in other foreign countries, it had obtained a court order freezing hundreds of bank accounts in the United...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that based on a review of bank records seized in Panama after the American invasion, as well as in other foreign countries, it had obtained a court order freezing hundreds of bank accounts in the United States suspected of having been used to hide nearly $400 million in

headline.main: Accounts Seized in Inquiry On Colombian Drug Profits

byline.original: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Addressing a trade group the other day, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter complained that he had ''taken a lot of flak'' for supposedly seeking to cut farm subsidies by $1.5 billion when he actually favored a $2 billion increase.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Addressing a trade group the other day, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter complained that he had ''taken a lot of flak'' for supposedly seeking to cut farm subsidies by $1.5 billion when he actually favored a $2 billion increase.

headline.main: Many Interests at Stake as Farm Act Is Rewritten

byline.original: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: As President Bush's Cabinet-level Economic Policy Council met today to consider which countries to target for reprisal under 1988 trade legislation, Administration officials said that India was likely to remain on their ''hit list'' but that...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As President Bush's Cabinet-level Economic Policy Council met today to consider which countries to target for reprisal under 1988 trade legislation, Administration officials said that India was likely to remain on their ''hit list'' but that Brazil, like Japan, had worked its way off.

headline.main: India Is Expected to Remain On U.S. Trade 'Hit List'

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Bush dropped Japan today from a list of countries subject to reprisal tariffs because of what the United States regards as unfair trading practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: President Bush dropped Japan today from a list of countries subject to reprisal tariffs because of what the United States regards as unfair trading practices.

headline.main: U.S. Drops Japan From Target List

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Bush's decision to threaten only one country for maintaining ''unfair'' trade barriers this year won't satisfy protectionists who have their eyes on Japan. But it should minimize the backlash against America's bullying. Of the three...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: President Bush's decision to threaten only one country for maintaining ''unfair'' trade barriers this year won't satisfy protectionists who have their eyes on Japan. But it should minimize the backlash against America's bullying. Of the three he named last year - Japan, Brazil and India - only India was named again and, wisely, no more were added.

headline.main: Making the Best of a Bad Trade Law

docs.snippet: LEAD: * Gloria Appel has joined Grey Advertising as a senior vice president for account management.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Rich and poor countries reached agreement today on a declaration setting out new priorities for speeding up economic growth in the developing world in the 1990's after a difficult debate that ran longer than expected.

headline.main: Rich and Poor Lands Agree On Path to Economic Growth

byline.original: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: He doesn't look fast when he walks. On the contrary, with his short, tapered legs and stocky, overstuffed torso, each step seems a struggle, as if he is sloshing through deep snow beneath a heavy backpack.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Trade negotiators reported no significant breakthroughs after the second day of talks among the United States, Japan, Canada and the 12-nation European Community.
